I don't fault the staff for this, but I do think it was kind of crappy that the owner walked by my table several times and HAD to notice the empty plates.  He was the one that brought them to us after all.  Anyway, all I am saying here is, the food is still good, but maybe they should rethink their whole dining room "chi" crap.  Fast, slow, whatever.  People still expect some timely service.

I have been wanting to try this restaurant for about 5 months and finally went in today and placed a carry out lunch order.  I got an entree sized greek salad with no olives and no onions and a pastrami sandwich for my husband.  My salad was good, but olives came in it.....however, the portion size was very small for $12.  I would expect almost twice as much and I am not a big eater.  My husband said his sandwich was pretty good.  I will go back and give it another shot but doubt I will eat there- the decor and environment seemed more suited to an older crowd and it was very busy!!
Great soup selection and specials.  My new favorite spot when I return to Madison.

My fiancÃ© and I took my mom here since she really enjoys the crepes. I had neither been here before nor had I heard of it, but was fine giving it a whirl for my mother.  The only thing I can REALLY remember is that the table was awfully sticky and my server made way more eye contact than was comfortable.  We walked in and I could tell the ambiance they were going for and noticed the "no cell phone" sign. I have to agree with other guests about this policy, on the weekends it's fine, but if it were a weekday I don't think it is reasonable to enforce because of work obligations. I could see asking people to silence their ringer, but a lot of people that go out to lunch during the workday need to have an idea of what's going on when they get back into the office.  The only thing I could think of was that they wanted to turn over tables faster and according to a recent study people on their phones generally take longer to complete a meal.  Anyway, I was a little disappointed they only had their brunch menu available since I really wanted to order a specific salad from the lunch menu I saw online, but alas, I ordered the House Cured Wild-Caught Salmon Omelet off the brunch menu and it tasted like a brick of cream cheese.  It was okay, but the pile of greens with a berry vinegarette didn't really complement the salmon omelet. Also, the salmon omelette had WAY WAY too much cream cheese. I had to open the omelet up to dig some of it out and It almost seemed the extra cream cheese was to cover up the fact that there was a very small amount of salmon in it. I felt ripped off.  My mom's crepes were good, my fiancÃ©'s food was forgettable (I can't even remember what he had!) and the service was nice, but to be honest, it was awkward, at least for me.  I am not someone who makes a lot of eye contact, so this may be a personal thing, but I was uncomfortable with how much eye contact she would make when she would ask if I wanted more water.   I mean...just read your customers a bit better...I felt like she was staring at me a lot and I'd glance up and it was a hard stare.  Overall, I would take my mom here again if she wanted to go, but I wouldn't choose it on my own or recommend it to a group of friends.

I had a cheeseburger with a side salad.  Like always,I love places that provide a salad rather than a potato.  I like their mantra of true food.  The food was great, flavorful but simple.  That is where my praise ends.  The restaurant is in a strip mall and parking is difficult to find.  The location is in a very busy area and if you are not familiar with street, you will pass it (at least once).  My GPS showed it was next to IHOP.  Read: IT IS ACROSS FROM IHOP.  Do not make my mistake.  The sign is not large, neither is the address.    Honestly, it is just too pricey without really being impressive.  True food does not need be expensize,

Eat here twice on a recent visit to this great city. Once was for lunch, had a delicious salad with grilled chicken, field greens and fresh strawberries. Others at our table had a nice looking burger, a French dip sandwich and a different salad. Service was excellent and all the food was fresh, tasty and very nicely presented.  We went back for Sunday brunch which was also yummy.  My omelet was cooked perfectly and the asparagus was fresh and flavorful.  Again service was attentive without being hovering or smarmy.  I really liked the eclectic decor and didn't think it was 'grandma -y' at all. I liked the vibe a lot and would happily return on our next visit to Madison.
I think the pastries in the front are disappointing. I've been here several times for brunch and once for dinner. The items on the brunch menu were excellent. Tasty food and attentive service. A+

Great place for breakfast with good French coffee and live piano. The decor is very cozy and you might feel like you are in France enjoying a cup of coffee and its charm. The morning bun was very moist and crunchy on the outside. It was not too sweet which is how I like it

La Brioche is the type of place that you want to go on a late Saturday morning order a couple mimosas and brunch and just sit for a couple hours. I love the ambiance of the place, I always try to snag a table with the really comfy chairs.

10/10 would come back for brunch! It's a lovely atmosphere - someone was playing the piano live. We also sat in really comfy, large chairs. And our waitress was attentive and funny.   I ordered the Vegetarian Eggs Benedict with garlic mashed potatoes and was in heaven! The Benedict comes on a croissant with asparagus - nice change from your typical Benedict. The garlic potatoes are to die for and the croissant was light and fluffy - exactly as it should be.   They have a cafe in the front too with baked goods and drinks available for purchase, which was great to tide me over until a table was ready. We came around 11:15 on a Sunday for 2. We were told the wait was a half hour but did not wait that long.   All around great find!
I was in La Brioche recently and the service seems to have gone downhill. The food was still good, however.
Excellent food. Omelettes generous and flavorful. Service was fast and pleasant. Good amount of gluten-free options. Great place for brunch.

You know what I liked about La Brioche today? The waiter and how kind he was to my Mom in her wheelchair. Food's ok, but not as awesome as the prices pretend., or what our memories insist from a lifetime ago. Mocha was enormous, though, and delicious. Gracias, Eduardo.

Any weekend visit to Madison should include brunch at La Brioche. Between the delightful food selection and the charming decor and ambience, it's always a worthwhile stop.   The vegetarian options are wonderful - the vegetarian eggs benedict and chilaquiles are both fine examples. The greens they serve with the egg dishes are always fresh and perfectly dressed with balsamic. And I always get a pot of tea (only $3!) since the owner collects the most adorable tea pots and the teas are delicious.   I also appreciate their efforts to keep the space a technology free zone. I've never had a hard time following the "no cell phone" rule because the occasion of sharing a meal with friends or family takes precedence anyway. But it's truly refreshing in today's world to have a break and just enjoy.   I've only ever had good experiences here and would recommend it to anyone.

Such a lovely place to have dinner! Decor is stunning with antique sofa chairs and dainty tables - you wouldn't be able to tell how frenchesque the decor is by the outside. Service was great and attentive even when a little understaffed.   Food: Comp bread - really great selection and came out hot and fresh! Squid Ink Pasta - sauce was good and the pasta was al dente. The mix of toppings with corn and green/red peppers kind of threw me off and little too much for the dish.  Lamb Pappardelle - super delish! Lamb was pulled and very soft, great ragu and pasta cooked nicely. Would recommend trying! Dessert- you walk in to this wonderful display of desserts and you see this gigantic creme puff eclair - we had to get it! And it was delicious. Even with the enormous size, the pastry was light and airy and creme was not too sweet.  If you're looking for a cute spot to eat, La Brioche is the place!

A great place for a relaxed brunch. Three different sections of the room are decorated in different themes. The back feels like a room out of the French Quarter in New Orleans. The front is light and airy. Great food, good service.

The burger was well above average and the potatoes that came with it were fantastic. Everything tastes real...or shall I say "True".    I respect their local sourcing and organic bend.  Service was just fine.  We ate outside.  We'll be back.

I was really torn about whether or not to try La Brioche, due to other Yelper reviews. We decided to toss the dice, and stopped in for brunch this morning.   Yes the decor is...interesting. I don't love it or hate it(although, ladies, you must go into the bathroom...just to see the Citrus Peacock wallpaper. Can't decide if it's so ugly it's cute, or just ugly).   I know service was a big disappointment for other people, but our waitress was average. It was fairly busy in the front, and we chose to sit in back where there were less families with loud children(we're not haters, we just hadn't had any coffee yet).   I tried the feta scramble..which was mediocre. Not bad, but nothing outstanding. The potatoes we split were yummy, and my croissant was good, as mentioned before. My boyfriend's French Toast was amazing. The candied pecans and bananas were good, but the creme anglaise pushed the dish over the top to heavenly. A decadent but delicious way to start any Sunday!  We both thought that the prices were fair, and we'd try it again.

I've been here a couple of times for lunch and for dinner. The food has always been good, the service has been really good. It is a bit spendy for what you get and the interior is a little over the top, but I've been there three times so far so that hasn't stopped me.

La Brioche where you can eat organic food while dining in decor more suited for a nursing home.   After coming here a few times now, I truly don't get this place.  I instantly feel 20 years old when I walk in-gaudily upholstered chairs, a piano player in the corner, and stain glass lamps on some of the tables. I respect and value the local, organic food scene as much as the typical Madisonian but listing that your water is not only filtered but also fluoride free is reaching too far.  Even if I agreed that fluoride is the next big evil in the world, me having two glasses with my meal certainly won't kill me. Speaking of meals, I feel La Brioche does a solid job in their offerings.  However, their price points are way too high.  A bacon, egg, and cheese croissant will set you back $10.25 and with a side of berries, the grand total is nearly $16.00.  There are way too many other places in Madison that not only deliver on the food but also don't have the decor of a Golden Girls set.
Cute place with great food! Loved the sweet "high tea" ambiance. A nice place to meet a friend for brunch.
Oh the breakfast tacos!  This place is not cheap but you're getting what you pay for.  Top-notch quality.

Great location, beautiful designed interior, stone oven, food and bakery. Don't get the poached salmon my advice get everything else. Everytime we go it's full. Be aware that in the winter it can be a little chilly inside, in the summer outside seating is great. Heads up no dinner service Sundays and Mondays. Tip: some of the vegetarian options can have meat added for the conscious carnivors

The food here was really great- the vanilla challah french toast was very good, the eggs Benedict were unique, hollandaise a little sweet. Egg dishes came with a great little mixed green salad. Beautiful ambience, especially considering that they are in a strip mall. Only issue was the service- it seemed a little distracted and borderline pretentious. I'd come back though.

I was excited to see chilaquiles, an authentic mexican breakfast on the menu. No one there had any idea what this stuff was. The waitress set down the dish saying "Here's your, uh, chilli". It didn't seem like the cook knew what chilaquiles was either. I swear they used feta cheese instead of queso fresco as described on the menu. The tortillas were just a stack of 6 or so pulled out of the bag and plopped onto the plate. You're supposed to cut up and fry your day old tortillas.   It came with the standard baguette and salad as sides, which are kind of weird to have with mexican. After eating a bunch of corn tortilla, you're not pining for a baguette. Some of the salad greens were rotten.  My kid had scrambled eggs and fruit, which looked amazing. I was jealous of him.   Their food looks mostly good, but maybe you should stick to the menu staples.

Stopped in by myself for breakfast. The host took me over to a table by the windows and stated "There is a 40 degree chill right here" then proceeded to seat me there anyway. I didn't quite realize what he had said until I felt chilly and noticed an air vent directly above me blowing cold air onto me. 10 minutes later I was really cold and considered asking to be moved but my coffee service had already arrived and I didn't want to be a pain.  The food was decent, the eggs Benedict was the most lemony version I've ever had. The side of greens was soaked in balsamic but luckily I like that sort of thing. Coffee was very good. My waitress was rather indifferent in personality, but still competent and attentive.  La Brioche asks that patrons do not use cell phones which makes me wonder how this place has so many photos and check-ins. Somebody's gotta be on their phone... One thing that stood out to me was the woman who was seated directly behind me who talked very loudly about her job in the medical field, including graphic descriptions of patient's bodily fluids. Any bodily excretion you can think of, she was shouting away about it. Why are people like this??? I realize that's not the restaurant's fault in any way, but I lost my appetite and it colored my experience. I might go back if others suggest it but probably won't return here as a solo diner.

Went to Saturday lunch today.  The positive. It's a beautiful spot. Lots of ambiance and beautifully landscaped. Also the piano music was very nice.  The negative. The sandwiches and soup were not very good. One of my guests ordered a Reuben. It was cold, not even heated through. We sent it back. The next Reuben was hot, but the pretzel it was served on was hard and dry. The Reuben had a lot of orange French dressing on it. I thought at first it was melted Velveeta. French dressing on a Reuben is a first. I've never seen that before. My hamburger was so so.   In general, it looked like more money was spent on landscaping than on quality kitchen staff. Suggest having coffee here perhaps and soaking up the ambiance and eating elsewhere.

i met a friend here for lunch today. we were both a bit thrown by the decor and overall atmosphere... i think we were envisioning more of a cafe than a place to have high tea, and we were definitely the only two people in the joint who were not privileged housewives or ancient lunching ladies.   i ordered a half a roast beef sandwich and a cup of potato soup. my friend had a reuben and some tea. my soup and sandwich were alright. the ciabatta that my sandwich was on was probably the best part of the meal.   overall, it wasn't great, but it wasn't bad either. i had heard rave reviews about it but i left disappointed. i might try this place again for dinner or brunch, but i can think of better lunch options.

Wow, I'm a little surprised about the negative reviews too. I love coming here for a special bunch or going out for coffee with my mom. They've got a nice menu with very good food and really good service. Comfy chairs inside and a cute patio outside. For lunch I really like their grilled cheese sandwich.  I've always loved their pastries and cookies (yes, I am a grown-up)  Next time you need to bring a cake for something, they make REALLY good cakes that you can order with a couple of days notice or buy on the spot.  And, they have yummy coffee/espresso drinks! I stopped here this morning for breakfast on the go and got the croissant sandwich, which was a very generous size. The good news is that meals come with a fresh salad (a good mix of greens). That way you can feel better about finishing all of your food. Next time, I think I'm going to have the breakfast tacos - or the crepes.

Brunch Club hit La Brioche this week to step up our barely-A.M. dining. The place was surprisingly glamorous considering it is in a plaza off University across from IHOP. The decor is elegant-meets-eclectic and they have a whole thing about the feng shui of the place (really... you can read about it here: http://labriochetruefood.com/feng-shui.html).  Anyway, ze food. I got Old World Porridge (I know, not the sexiest option and nothing to write home about) but it was one of the few veggie options available that time of day. My brunchmates got the feta scramble (eggs, feta, sundried tomatoes, arugula) and Black Forest ham/cheddar/asparagus omelette respectively. They both enjoyed their meals but we agreed the prices were a little steep. To be fair! Many of the menu items were organic and local (eggs, salad mix, tomatoes, berries), which is ia big draw to come back and give it another go.  The service was great-- our waitress was bubbly and helpful answering our questions. I'd go back to try another meal...perhaps dinner? They have a long list of stone oven pizzas and house-made pastas that look damn enticing...

I can't even begin to count the number of times my husband or I have said, "We should try La Brioche one of these days." Well, we finally did it. We had friends in town for the weekend and decided a bunch at La Brioche would be a great way to kick off a Saturday.   The parking lot was packed when we got there at 10am, which led me to think it would be busy in the restaurant, but I'd say the place was 1/2-3/4 full (I think people had used the parking lot for a swim meet next door). There were tables available outside and it was a gorgeous morning so we sat outside (it was also pretty loud inside, lots of people talking and loud music, which I personally don't enjoy when dining with friends).   Our waitress was polite and friendly. There are standard coffee choices (black, latte, mocha) in addition to a few fancier things (Miel, Matcha Latte, etc). Since it was brunch, that was the menu we worked with. There are simply too many choices (I kinda wish it had been a bit paired down), but I went with the Vanilla Challah French Toast with bananas and toasted pecans. It was THE BEST DECISION EVER! The bread was warm and custardy, and while they served it with a side of maple syrup - there was no need to add to my impending diabetic coma. My husband had the eggs benedict which did not disappoint. A third member of our group tried the daily quiche (there's a meat and a veggie option) which was Bacon Cheeseburger this particular morning. All said, we had a beautiful brunch with delicious food, drink, and company.   Prices are a bit higher, but honestly not horrible. I wouldn't spend this much on a weekly basis, but once a month isn't out of the question.   The last thing I really liked was a sign on the door and a listing on the menu that asked patrons to refrain from using cell phones and laptops in the restaurant. While I'm sure that will ruffle a few coffee shop regulars, I found it refreshing to be away from technology if only for an hour.

Sunday brunch here is fantastic! Sitting in the old fashioned high backed arm chairs nestled up to a little table, sipping on local organic coffee and debating whether or not the cinnamon buns should be eaten now, or later! The food is good, nothing fancy but super tasty. We had the four cheese quiche and the chilequildelia (spelling?) both of which are perfectly portioned. The side of roasted potatoes is enough to share, so be careful. The bakery was delicious, the chocolate croissant was incredible and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for something not to heavy but sweet!

It's not my first time.....but we did NOT enjoy the food today.  The salad was "tired".....two or more days old.  The Croissant was old - not fresh as it should.  And the bread was not fresh.  And the server was "not nice" - nothing specific but "not nice" is the right terms here.  We visit here more than few times but today was a disappointed visit

Just over a year after the first review, I find myself here again.  This time, the goal was to create a meal out of two individual items that would,  when consumed a la carte be considered a snack.  I zeroed in on a small cherry walnut salad ($7) and a fish taco ($7).  An expensive snack/meal to be sure, and I was left with mixed results.  The salad is reliably satisfying creation that has a distinct composite envelope of flavor and texture.  The mixed greens, parmesan, dried cherries and vinaigrette dressing were pleasing enough, though nothing about it beckoned for a return visit anytime soon.  The fish taco was an entirely different and much more disappointing experience.  While the idea of fish tacos is nothing new, and even the inclusion of tilapia is now a fairly standard option, the unpleasant surprise here was the extra step of infusing a hickory-smoked flavoring on the fish, with only a small bed of cilantro for contrast.  The resulting taste made me wonder if this menu item had been rescued from a recent structure fire, as the smoke aura was so monochromatic as to eliminate all other dimensions of flavor.  Perhaps a small dab of chipotle salsa as an additional accessory may have rescued this victim, but in it's current form, no such luck.  Incidentally, the entrees were a limited and expensive situation.  I believe it would be to the kitchen's advantage to consider a more seasonal menu, taking advantage of local seasonal produce, rather than a continuous merry-go-round of the same views.

The decor is awesome, I love it! They also make really good chai tea lattes and I enjoy having breakfast here (decent menu, a little pricey). However, the past three times that I have purchased a baked good, they have all been stale. I have had coworkers who have had stale bakery items as well in the past months or so. These stale items include cupcakes, muffins and scones. I love the ambiance, it is very home-y but stale baked goods for a bakery like La Brioche is disappointing.

This place is just a treasure!! It's so cozy classy and quaint. The food is so pure & delicious and fresh tasting!! I had heard great things about this place so my gf & I had to check it out & have a girls brunch. We loved it and had a blast. Eggs Benedict insane delish & she had breakfast tacos & raved about them!!

I went here to meet a friend from out of town for breakfast on a Wednesday morning around 8:30. It was not super busy, but also not as empty as I would have guessed for a random weekday. The staff person at the front counter was very friendly. There appeared to be plenty of staff on hand. Despite this, I was really surprised at the slow service. I wasn't timing anything, but it took abnormally long for her to come over to greet us, take our orders, refill coffee, and bring the check. I would usually give a pass for this in a very busy place with only one server, but this was not the case. Overall, the food was excellent! I think the prices are a little high, but the ingredients are high quality and the food is cooked well. It's worth the price. I was surprised at the coffee though -- $3 for one cup of regular coffee?! It wasn't really anything special to me, although it was noted as being local in the menu. One could argue you are paying for a quality, local product, but still, $3+ is what I pay for specialty drinks, not a plain cup of coffee. I would go back for the great tasting food and hope the service was just a random experience.

Great food! And great ambience! The food service could be faster though. It took close to 10 minutes before the waitress greeted us. And be careful which time you go because the menu changes. I do highly recommend their desserts. YUM!
We've taken the kid here several times for sunday brunch. To be honest, the experiences have been un-impressive.

I came here with some family members for my college graduation. I was so surprised to see the restaurant empty because 1. all of the other restaurants I tried booking were completely full with graduation reservations and 2. La Brioche is always so packed for brunch time.  To be honest, I'm not the biggest fan of their brunch. I heard so many great things about the brunch and was a little disappointed. HOWEVER, the dinner menu is great. I really enjoyed eating their wild-caught salmon. The portion size is big, and more importantly, it's delicious. The owner mentioned something about knowing a guy who goes to Alaska twice a year and brings back a lot of wild salmon.  Their desserts are also really good. My favorite is the tres leches cake. The first one I ever tried was here, and it was so good I started craving tres leches all the time afterwards. I tried tres leches cake at other restaurants was learned that the one I had at La Brioche is pretty different from the typical one - however, I find it to be better tasting.  5-stars to the owners and waitstaff for their friendly service and attentiveness.

Nice bakery food with friendly service  Went here for brunch on Saturday.  Lots of selections for us egg eaters.  I had a good scramble with standard greens.  The balsamic didn't really go with my scramble but it wasn't bad. The eggs Benedict looked amazing.  Others had a big cinnamon roll and a morning bun which is the real reason to go here.  Ya gotta have one of those!  Service was great.  Very attentive and asked all the right questions about the complicated drinks.  Even whether we wanted raisins on our rolls.  Nice brunch or lunch spot.  I would go again.

In summary,  La Pretentious/Truly over-hyped.  And I'm talking about both food and service.  For Sunday brunch, I ordered feta scramble, which came with unimpressive taste, accompanied by overdressed salad (major turn off) and a piece of whatever-grade toast - wait, they're supposed to be a bakery, right?  My bf's omelet - ugh, mentioning would be a waste of space. My friend's egg benedict - ordered with the poached egg medium done. What they brought out instead was wrong kind of egg benedict with super runny yolk that unfortunately decided to spill and ran to my friend's crotch. We sent it back and they brought us newly cooked mediocre dish.  Piece of advise: Perkin's omelet can give La Brioche a serious run for the money, not to mention that Perkin's also would have a lot more pleasant staff, and better Feng Shui. Who cares about the pages of brochure going on and on about the ugly decor? Give us the true good food and solid service, and that should be enough to put patrons in good mood.

Here we go again. So many people told me how good this place was. I don't know what they are eating or what they are comparing it to, it is horrible. Jay P. who says he is from DC, nailed the description of the omelette perfectly. The service is abysmal, which really hurts a restaurant such as this. When you can't fall back on the food to be good, and your service fails you, you have nothing left. The name implies 'french." One bite of a croissant tells you it should be called La Pillsbury. The coffee is good, but it is no secret, it's Kickapoo, which is a pretty good coffee.  The bland food, the horrible croissant, the uninteresting and dated selection of menu choices does nothing to bring me back, and it won't.

I have had the most horrible experience at this restaurant on several occassions.  And, these experiences could be very costly for me.  I have decided (un-wisley) to use Labrioche as a meeting place with potential clients.  On two separate occasions I made arrangements to meet a client for coffee or lunch and asked the manager that I was waiting for someone.  On both occasions, the person I was meeting was sitting at the restaurant also waiting for someone to meet them.  Both times, I sat and waited and consistently asked wait staff and other staff is there was someone waiting for someone and they would say no.  The person I was meeting was consistently asking as well and they were told the same thing.  I was waiting inside the restaurant the person I was meeting was sitting outside.  I asked if there was someone waiting outside and I was told no.  Although, my friend was asking the same question and she was told no.  This has happened twice, the same time, same staff and unfortunately with the same person.  I have gotten better service at Denny's of IHOP.  There is some kind of communication breakdown, because I have seen this happen with other people too.

This place is excellent. Decor is soothing and classy. Jas the waitress was friendly and prompt. Our fresh food, I had green eggs and ham, was flavorful, not too filling, healthy and fresh. My only issue is it's a tad overpriced for what you get. Definitely and must place in Madison for brunch.

I don't get the allure.  Is it the furniture?  The water pitchers?   When I go out to eat I want food that tastes great. It's why I have decided not to cook and actually leave my abode to go spend money somewhere else. And the food I've had just doesn't wow me. Now I've only been for breakfast, so maybe things really get exciting around lunchtime? Add to this the fact that servers are a bit aloof (I find myself having to repeatedly ask for things) and the insane prices for eggs (I get the whole true food thing, I do) and it's just not a place I'll find myself returning to soon.

After reading all these reviews, I decided to give La Brioche a try because I love pastries.   Unfortunately, I will have to say that for 75 cents less--Whole Foods croissants are better than La Brioche. The chocolate croissant I got from La Brioche was DRY and not buttery or flaky like it's suppose to be. The chocolate inside the chocolate croissant was also CHEAP CANDY MELTS! For a restaurant that tries to advertise organic and wholesome food products, I would expect them to use a better chocolate. Not only was the croissant dry, but the croissant was also tough to chew and felt like it was a few days old. I felt like I was eating cardboard instead of a croissant. I definitely won't be getting pastries from La Brioche in the future!    If you are looking for good pastries, then I would recommend going to Graze near the downtown capital square during farmer's market! Their pastries are so fresh, warm, soft, and delicious! I am in love with s'more cronut!!!
If I didn't know how awful they treat their employees I'd give this a three to four star rating. I also witnessed cockroaches.

Go here for brunch! My husband and I went to La Brioche on a Saturday morning and were not disappointed. We had a short wait, but it was worth it for the food. We tried an omelette and the open-faced roasted vegetable sandwich and both were very good.  Make sure to save room for dessert. They're bakery case is full of decadent treats. The cream puff was just ok, but the red velvet cupcake was great!  We also appreciated the little touches like the good service & cute decor.

I was a regular at their original location. It was 100% Mom and Pop, right down to the vinyl gingham table "cloths" and napkin dispensers on the tables.  Now, if you stop in to buy something from the bakery (which is primarily what the last location was - a bakery), you're not treated very well - almost like you're wasting the staff's time.  Plus, $2 for a glass of milk for my kid - I don't think so. I'd take the old place back in a heart beat, but the pretentiousness and price of this new version are a real let down.

First time to la brioche and the entire experience was stellar! Speedy host, despite the line of people and practically full restaurant, and we were able to get the outside table we requested. Waitress was efficient with delivering our bloody Mary's after her eloquent description of the flavors. Food took appropriate amount of time and the portions were perfect for a hungry man, and I had a few leftovers, primarily the delicious breakfast potatoes.   Food: eggs Benedict, spicy Bloody Mary, breakfast potatoes. The asparagus on the Benedict was a nice touch, in addition to the croissant breading. Bloody had infused peppers in the vodka, so the Tabasco flavor wasn't present. Very well described by Andrea and the spicy was a slow creep of strength. Potatoes needed more salt but had great flavor!  Service: waitress was very knowledgeable and checked on us an appropriate amount of times. Andrea was a self proclaimed foodie and I can now confirm, she knew it well and left me satisfied.   Will be returning again!

La Brioche is very close to my work place.  My usual visits are a quick stop for a morning bun and the Double Miel to go.  I find the staff friendly and quick.  My dining-in experiences are less frequent and are, again, usually in the morning for the breakfasts.  I had a surprise visit from a former coworker so we decided to met up at La Brioche for dinner this past Tuesday.  I got there first and was snagged a four top for my group ( one in a wheelchair ).  I got the table set up right for the group and ordered the Earl Mint tea for my wait.  Loose leave tea and a nice sized tea pot of hot water was brought.   I mixed in a little honey and it was so good.  I may have to come in the morning early for the newspaper and tea before work.  My wait (for my friends) was a bit longer than I expected.  The server was considerate to check on me periodically.  I did take my phone out for a quick text to see where my group was.  I respect their rule about cell phones.  It makes the space more relaxing without tables all chatting up their phones.  And since my phone was out, I snapped a picture of the menu and of the tea.  I am a Yelper, after all!  When my group finally arrived, I ordered the Quiche Lorriane.  It is served with potatoes and salad but I asked if I could exchange the potatoes for acorn squash.  They did and that was such a good choice.  I really like the salad, too.  It is dressed with a balsamic dressing that is very good.  The Quiche was good and I would get it again.  Price points for the restaurant are a bit high but the quality of food is there so I'm okay with it.  La Brioche is a nice relaxing restaurant.

I have only been here for brunch.  I would say it's good and I would go again but not quite worth of a 5 star review.  Waiter service was good except that I was lacking water at the end of my meal.  FYI, this place is notorious for banning any sort of laptop or cellphone use inside their restaurant. Hot chocolate: very good but you MUST get the larger size, the smaller is in a teacup. Old world porridge: strangely good. At first I thought, "man, this is not very good" but it grew on me and I went back for it again.  It is served with old fashioned oats and cream rather than just water.  Brown sugar and a small portion of berries are on the side. Breakfast potatoes: these stand out a bit because they are super garlicky!  I thought they were good but they were much more garlicky than any other breakfast potato I've had. Quiche with ham: This is the winner!  I'm not a quiche person but I think this is the best quiche I've ever had and my dining companion agreed.  Fun fact: go here just before close and you can get 6 morning buns for $5, a steal considering that 1 morning bun is about $2.50 at normal prices

What a cute place! I love the comforting/cozy atmosphere at La Brioche. We had a very kind waitress who was personable and talkative, and the food was overall pretty good!     I started off with a butter croissant, which was very tasty. Only complaint is that the butter to spread onto the croissant wasn't very soft so it made it pretty difficult to spread, however the croissant tasted great without the extra butter :)    Each of us eating that morning ordered something different:   One friend had the  Vanilla Challah French Toast -- made with crÃ¨me Anglaise and her choice of berries (otherwise you can choose caramelized pecans and bananas). She absolutely loved it, and I had a bite and must say it was delicious! Definitely get this is you're looking for something sweet for breakfast.     On the other hand, my other friend and myself went with the savory options. I'm pretty sure my friend ordered something off of their breakfast specials menu -- which was made with potatoes, eggs, veggies (mushrooms, peppers, onions, etc.) and she opted to add breakfast sausage into the mix as well. It looked great, and she said she really liked it!     For me, I had the Feta Scramble -- made with eggs, feta, sundried tomatoes, and arugula. It was served with the organic spring mix salad and a slice of baguette on the side. While the scramble was good, I don't think I'd get it again. It felt as though there was not much egg in the scramble, and there was a lot of arugula. I love arugula, but I felt like there was something lacking -- maybe some meat? I think next time I would ask to add sausage to it or go with another menu item, since I left satisfied, but not very full. If I wouldn't have had the croissant beforehand, I think I would have still been hungry after eating!     Overall, I really do like La Brioche and I know I'll be making return visits in the future! I'd love to try their Pesto "Green Eggs and Ham" Scramble next time. Their menu seems a bit more expensive than other breakfast options in the area -- but I think the extra few dollars are worth it every once in a while :)

I was so disappointed in the food here. The only thing that was good was the tomato bisque soup. I had 1/2 beef sandwich which was horrible also. Took 4 scones home and threw them in the garbage, they were all tasteless. I would skip La Brioche, there are so many other terrific restaurants in Madison, don't waste your money here.

The pastries are great, and the environment is cozy. But I have to say, the service here is terrible. I stopped in today to buy a box of pastries to bring to work. I told the young woman at the counter I wanted a dozen pastries. She asked me how many I wanted.  She then chose a box and began filling it with pastries according to my direction. But the box did not hold a dozen pastries and she had to put several additional pastries in a separate paper bag. I asked if it was possible to have a shopping bag that I could carry both the box and bag in. She told me that they had shopping bags, but that the boxes they have would not fit in the bag.  While we were having this discussion, another woman came in asking to order a large iced tea. The staffer at the counter chose a cup and began to fill it, at which point the customer said that that was not the size she usually got.  The staff person replied that they were out of the larger cups. No apology, no offer to fill two instead of one, nothing. The customer finally said that she would go elsewhere for her tea and left.  They seemed unconcerned. Meanwhile, I struggled to my office with a bag of pastries balanced on top of a box. Rarely do I have the experience of dropping $40 and feeling like the business where I'm spending my money is doing me a favor.  Come on, guys, get it together.

I thought I had figured out how to have a good meal at La Brioche: take out.  I very much enjoy the organic burger and some of the omelets, and, with take out, I had been able to avoid the horrible service.  Alas, no more.    I called in an order for my usual burger with avocado and swiss, stating I would be right over.  I arrived, paid for it, and waited.  And waited.  I checked, only to find that the person who took my call had indicated that I would pick it up one hour later than I had said.  No apology from the staff involved, barely an apology from another staff member, and certainly no gesture like, "Please, have a pastry on us."  I am done with True Foods.  Madison has a number of other restaurants with better food and much, much better service.  Incidentally, while waiting for my missing order, I discovered how to get good service at True Food: have a relationship with a staff member.  A young women who was apparently attached in some fashion (girlfriend?) to a staff member received lavish attention from that person and other staff.  So, unless you are related to someone who works at True Food, look elsewhere.

Cute atmosphere, good bread, and acceptable food. This place is nothing to write home about but it is perfectly good enough, has comfortable seating, a lovely patio, and good service. Most importantly, as far as I am concerned, they don't make you feel rushed while eating, even when service is busy. Also, at brunch their veggie eggs Benedict is quite tasty; however there aren't a ton of options for vegetarians who prefer savory food to sweets.

Should be 4.5 stars, but no way to give it that. The food is good. The bakery items are amazing. We had a party of five arrive at 9:30am on a Sunday, and although they told us we would wait for 50-60 minutes, it really was only 15 minutes. I definitely recommend getting there early on Sunday morning for brunch. They let us have free coffee and tea while we waited. The coffee and tea was delicious! The noise level was pretty annoying the whole time (bad acoustics and lots of people talking) so we had to speak very loudly to each other. When we got to the table, we ordered some pastries right away. The cream puff for $5 was delicious and when split 5 ways, it worked out. I would not recommend trying to eat that huge thing with fewer people. The cream was perfect and stiff, the chocolate on top was excellent, and the strawberries on top and in the middle were a wonderful surprise. The morning bun was also very good, although those aren't really my thing. It didn't taste overly sugary though and it was wonderfully fresh and airy. The food itself was not quite as good as the bakery items. The side salads all had a slightly overwhelmingly bitter tasting vinaigrette. The vegetarian quiche was delicious except that it tasted like there was either bacon or lard somewhere in it. My dish was the breakfast tacos and I substituted cheddar cheese for the chorizo to make them vegetarian. It was good, but was missing a bold, unifying flavor. It probably would have been better with retried beans to pull all the other flavors together (especially if you're not going to have chorizo). My aunt ordered a fried egg, which was, you know, a fried egg. The garlic potatoes received mixed reviews from our table - some loved it and some thought they were greasy and not crispy enough. I thought they were good and very well seasoned.

A very decent place for lunch within a short distance from UW Hospital. I've eaten here twice now and the experience was consistently decent. Service is brisk and polite. Menu variety is ok and their mixed greens are consistently fresh and light. This is not my preferred style of food-an upscale Au Bon Pain if you will-so it's hard for me to be excited by it. But it is nice and eventually we all tire of hospital food.

I really can't believe that I'm saying this, but I think Brioche has knocked out my #1 and is my new favorite restaurant in Madison. Come here for a true dining experience; you won't be disappointed.  We went for brunch and it was pretty busy, but we didn't have to wait for a table. I got the mushroom omelet and my friend got the veggie benedict. Both were tasty, as were the greens that came with it and the soup we got as an appetizer.  We had to try something from the bakery too, so after asking our waitress for her recommendation, we took a morning bun to go (they're known for them). Also great.  The thing that gets me about this restaurant is that it's not a dinner (or a lunch, brunch, etc.); it's an experience. Everything in the place has been thought out and made as comfortable as possible. For example, the entire restaurant has been designed with feng shui concepts (and is explained in a little book on the table!), they serve reverse-osmosis water that's made onsite, and they have table lamps at the smaller tables.  Seriously, Brioche, A+. I will be back again VERY soon.

La Brioche is something that must be tried, but they have some big flaws and it's not something everyone will like.  First off, they have the best Croissant ever made.  Period.  I've been to the "actual" La Brioche in France, and I still like the Croissants here better than anywhere else, so that's saying a lot.  The Chocolate Croissants are equally as good, so don't skimp when you go there.  The Croissant has a nice hard shell (not hard like stale bread, good hard), and a creamy-butter taste that you'll be longing for after you leave.  Plus, almost zero flakiness like most other quality Croissant makers.  Secondly, the restaurant itself is fairly new (they used to have a small bakery down the street), and they did a nice job with the furnishings.  It looks very victorian vintage, with a unique color layout and pleasant dining areas.  There's also an outdoor section when it's nice outside, and a comfortable waiting area when they're busy.  Those things said, they have a HUGE problem with service.  At the old bakery, there was 1 or 2 curmudgeon employees who were extremely rude no matter how you approached them.  At this new restaurant, there's now a handful of people who share that behavior, except they also have inexperience and no tact to add to the list.  Additionally, the food items are hit or miss.  They all have a little something off about them, and the presentation is pretty basic considering the steep prices.  My Recommendation -   Stop in and buy a few Croissants, don't stay for lunch.

The food can be good but the service is arrogant and crappy.  They have no manager and the owner sits back in his office and rarely makes it out to see what is going on.  It's all a little overpriced too and the ambience is pretentious and stupid.  The place looks like a grandma on crack decorated it.  A restaurant in a strip mall should not be this pretentious.

This is my go-to brunch spot: consistent, high-quality ingredients and polite staff. If you are feeling indulgent, try a morning bun before they sell out. Otherwise the brioche french toast or feta scramble are wonderful.

The food is always good tasting but very overpriced. I ordered a small salad which seemed reasonably priced at $7, but I didn't read the menu closely and they added another $6 for chicken! I went there on a lunch date with the 2-year-old I was babysitting and they were very accommodating with the little one- they had lots of books and crayons and a great children's menu.  The brunch is also more expensive on the weekends than the weekdays, which I found out first-hand- next time I will be sure to check the menu before I go somewhere!

I have to agree with the reviewers who moved to Madison who are disappointed in the overall quality of Madison restaurants, yet remain hopeful (what else can you do?) that things might improve. I don't think La Brioche is helping things improve. To me, it felt like a really amateur attempt at a restaurant. The food was just not that interesting and the service was worse, but for me, the decor was the nail in the coffin! They took a nice contemporary kitchen and mixed it with these crazy upholstered barrel chairs that look like they went missing from the House on the Rock. Not going back.
